discussion.content: Extended Unique Identifier (EUI) allows a host to assign itself a unique 64-Bit IP Version 6 interface identifier. This feature is a key benefit over IPv4 as it eliminates the need of manual configuration on DHCP in the world of IPv4.

questions.question_text: A network technician wants to address PCs on a subnet with IPv6 in addition to IPv4. The subnet currently uses a DHCP server that only supports IPv4. Which of the following should the technician use to assign IPv6 addresses automatically without DHCP?

discussion.content: The answer is right please do not listen to these people. It's not in the Comptia Objectives.

Answer is right. Please refer to this link: https://proprivacy.com/vpn/guides/vpn-encryption-the-complete-guide. L2TP does not provide encryption unless used with IPSec. PPTP is an older encryption method that uses MSCHAPv2 and is now obsolete. Thus this makes IPSec the correct answer.
IPsec is encrypted.Comparatively more secure than PPTP. I guess in the question it was mentioned "securely".That's why IPSec was Chosen.

comments.content: PPTP is point to point, that is, network to network, not client-to-server. Study some more before speaking.

discussion.content: PPTP is definitely the correct answer
Wouldn't it be D.?

comments.content: PPTP is a Point to Point Tunneling Protocol, an older protocol that supports dial-up networks and lacks security features.

questions.question_text: A technician is establishing connectivity through a VPN for remote server access. Which of the following protocols should be utilized to configure this VPN connection securely?

discussion.content: I think its a hot site, but can see business continuity. Even more so though, this is a bad question. It does not test your knowledge of the subject matter but rater a personal interpretation of semantics.
Business continuity is the ongoing return to normalcy after an incident. A long term goal that takes place after an incident. A hot site is a much better fit for this question
https://www.techtarget.com/searchdisasterrecovery/definition/Business-Continuity-and-Disaster-Recovery-BCDR

There are other disasters that can happen that doesn't necessarily require a hot site. (i.e a core switch gets fried by a surge, business continuity includes having a redundant core switch (LEAF topology setup), but you don't really need a whole new site for this.
Redundancy plan would have been a better option considering the wording of the question.
it requires no down time, but hot site needs time to recover.
key word "a disaster recovery solution"

Definetly A
A hot site is a commercial disaster recovery service that allows a business to continue computer and network operations in the event of a computer or equipment disaster. For example, if an enterprise's data center becomes inoperable, that enterprise can move all data processing operations to a hot site. A hot site has all the equipment needed for the enterprise to continue operation, including office space and furniture, telephone jacks and computer equipment.
I believe A should be the right answer. Business continuity is the objective to be achieved, not a disaster recovery solution.

comments.content: I agree - I immediately thought of A.

discussion.content: Why isn't this a hot site?

comments.content: Then everything is a business continuity plan and theres no need for warm, hot, or cold sites
maybe because hot site is in the business continuity plan....it's a small part of the whole!

questions.question_text: A network technician receives a request for a disaster recovery solution. Management has requested no downtime in the event of a disaster. Which of the following disaster recovery solutions is the appropriate choice?

A network technician receives a new firmware update for a network device. The technician wants to ensure the file has not been tampered with. Which of the following techniques should the technician use to ensure the integrity of the file?

discussion.content: This is like the 10th question about hashing, yall better know what hashing is at this point. Lol
RADIUS uses UDP while TACACS+ uses TCP.

It seems that correct answer is A. RADIUS.
The AP uses UDP port number 1812 to connect to the RADIUS. 
Radius uses UDP port number 1812 for authentication and authorization and 1813 for accounting.
TACACS+ uses TCP port number 49.

More information:
https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/difference-between-tacacs-and-radius/
i really thought LDAP, but after reading the question again it is from an AP - remote user - radius fo sho

RADIUS: Radius is a protocol that enables a single server to become responsible for all remote-access authentication, authorization, and auditing (or accounting) services. It is an authentication and accounting system used by many Internet Service Providers (ISPs). When you dial in to the ISP you must enter your username and password. This information is passed to a RADIUS server, which checks that the information is correct, and then authorizes access to the ISP system. RADIUS implements a client/server architecture, where typical client is a router, switch, or AP and the typical server is a Windows or Unix device that is running RADIUS software.

questions.question_text: An AP is configured to authenticate clients by using their Active Directory username and password. The AP uses UDP to connect to the authentication service, which then queries Active Directory. Which of the following authentication services is being used by the AP in this scenario?
